title-group.article-title: Dynamic analysis of spherical film as sensing element for detecting micro-force

abstract.p: In order to realize the precise measurement of a micro-force in the biomedical domain and industrial fields, a type of spherical film, of about 700 nm thickness and 50 mm diameter, was used as sensing element to detect a nano-Newton (nN) level force. Distortions were observed when nN-level particles were placed on the spherical film or such level forces were applied on the spherical film. From the deformation of spherical film, we can obtain the gravity of the particle or applied force. A dynamic model of the spherical film was constructed using the ANSYS software. Adopting the orthogonal experimental method, we designed effective experimental parameters for numerical calculation and mainly focused on the relations among nN-level force, thickness and diameter of spherical film, and deformation parameters. Then a fitting formula describing the relationship between deformation, the thickness and diameter of the spherical film, and the loaded force was obtained from the experimental data using the least square algorithm. The error analysis of experimental and computational data showed that when controlling the force in the range of 20–160 nN, the detecting error was less than ±3.2%.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: The need to evaluate small forces in the range of 10 nN to 10 mN has increased both in industrial and research fields, especially in the biomedical field. Nowadays, cancer cell recognition and classification mainly depends on exterior morphology. Although different types of cancer cells may have the same shape, they usually possess different weights in the range of 10 nN to 1 mN. Quick evaluation of such small forces will enable doctors and analysts to diagnose and classify cancer at early stages, and take appropriate measures to save patients. Furthermore, recognition and classification of bacteria and animalcule though their weight is also a novel method in biological and chemical fields. However, it is difficult to measure micro-forces properly. Until today, there is no established method (Fujii et al., 2009) for measuring micro-Newton level forces, even for static force. Some methods to support a direct realization of micro-Newton level forces linked to the International System of Units (SI) below 1 N are currently being developed by some institutes. The small force to be measured is usually a time-varying force and no dynamic calibration technique for force sensors has yet been developed.

At present, the measurement of micro-forces is mainly performed by using piezoelectric transducer (PZT) or micro-electromechanical system (MEMS) techniques. Small piezoresistive force sensors of 200×200×640 μm3 have been developed to obtain haptic feedback of the forces acting on a guide wire’s tip during vascular catheterization (Meiss et al., 2011); the measured force was at the level of mN. A three-axis micro-force sensor (Muntwyler et al., 2010) with adjustable force range from ±20 to ±200 μN was designed and it was a novel microfabrication process based on a double silicon-on-insulator (SOI) substrate. A micro-machined silicon force sensor was designed to detect a blocking force at the mN level by measuring a change in voltage within a piezoresistor bridge. A 700-μm-long micro-cantilever showed a maximum displacement of 800 nm and a blocking force of 0.1 mN at an actuation voltage of 5 V (Duval et al., 2007). Huang and Chiu (2009) used piezoelectric material to generate a high-frequency oscillation for actuating a fingertip, which in was contact with a slide to induce a back-and-forth motion. The actuating force is at about the Newton level.

Furthermore, some scholars investigated the mechanical properties of thin film. The mechanical properties of thin film system were commonly measured using a micro- or nano-indentation test based on the contact mechanics principles (Oliver and Pharr, 2004). Zheng and Sridhar (2006) used a finite element method (FEM) to perform an accurate numerical analysis of the normal indentation of an elastic–plastic layered half-space by a rigid sphere, and estimated the relation between load, displacement and contact radius of an elastic thin film. Gramlich and Homsy (2006) determined the stability and perturbation growth rates for a spherical film expanding with time, focusing on the effects of the expansion on stability. According to the strain energy density function for finite deformation of viscoelastic material, the relaxation function of the Maxwell mode, and the deformation gradient tensor of the bubble, a stress equation for the finite deformation of a protein bubble was derived (Wang et al., 2007). By using the above stress equation and the dynamics equation of the bubble, an equation describing the relation between the relative deformation rate of the inner radius (about 1 mm) and time was developed for finite deformations. Iwata et al. (2010) predicted the surface tension and contact angle for Newtonian fluids by measuring the shape of a small bubble attached to a solid surface in the fluid. Wang et al. (2010) numerically investigated the effects of surface tension on the behaviour of an initially spherical buoyancy-driven bubble rising in an infinite and initially stationary liquid by the volume of fluid method. In addition, some researchers focused on the investigation of bubble viscosity and dynamics in different fluids (Albernaz and Cunha, 2011; Ansari and Nimvari, 2011).

There are some common disadvantages in the use of thin film micro-force sensors, such as piezoelectric effect, piezoresistive effect and gas sensitivity: the preparation procedure of thin films is complex; the anti-jamming performance is not good; and the application environment is extremely limited. Some scholars have investigated the stability and stress characteristics of spherical film. Previously, there has not been a study using spherical film as a sensing element to measure micro-forces. The spherical film has following advantages: the manufacturing process of spherical films is relatively simple; the product scale of spherical film goes beyond that of MEMS films; as a sensing element, a spherical film has anti-electromagnetic interference. In this paper, the micro-strain feature of a spherical film with the diameter about 50 mm is utilized to measure micro-forces at the nN level. The relations among spherical film deformation, spherical film diameter, spherical film thickness and the applied micro-force on a spherical film are explored to measure the micro-force.

sec.title: Experiments and method
sec.p: Figure 1 shows the experimental set-up to measure the micro-force using a spherical film as a sensing element. The measurement system is composed of a 3D motion platform, motor drivers, micro-gripper, spherical film, industrial camera and IPC. Under a natural light environment, interference fringes are present on the surface of the spherical film, which are then caught and converted into digital images by the industrial camera. The micro-gripper for holding the micro-particle approaches the spherical film, controlled by the 3D motion platform, and stops moving when it is about 1 mm above the spherical film. Then the micro-particle is loaded on the bubble and the micro-gripper returns back to its starting position. Subsequently, the bubble deforms and the interference fringes are verified. We obtain two different images of interference fringes before and after loading; the difference between the two images reflects the mass or gravity of the micro-particle. Thus, the micro-force can be measured by analysing the difference between the two interference images. Image recognition and processing may utilize the wavelet analysis method (Omar and Gaouda, 2011) or morphological skeleton methods (Udrea and Vizireanu, 2007; Vizireanu and Udrea, 2009; Vizireanu et al., 2003, 2010).

caption.p: Experimental system of measuring micro-force by spherical film.

sec.p: The diameter and thickness of the spherical film always influence the results of the measurement. If the scale of diameter is too large, the stability of the bubble is not good, and if the scale of diameter is too small, the magnitude of deformation is small, which results in low measurement resolution and low precision. Therefore, we construct a dynamic model of the spherical film based on the FEM, and analyse the relation between the loaded micro-force and deformation of the bubble. In the end, the dynamic equation relating the micro-force to the diameter, thickness and deformation of the bubble is obtained, which can be utilized to guide experimental research in the future.

Equation (1) is a non-linear Lienard equation; thus the solution will be vibrant or degressive. This is an analytical solution available for the deformation of a bubble with a radius of about 1.0 mm, which is far less than the 25 mm used in our research. Furthermore, x is a contraction ratio and the diameter of the bubble is degressive. Therefore, it is imperative to obtain the numerical solution of Equation (1).

In order to analyse accurately the characteristics of a spherical film between the deformation and micro-force, finite element simulation software is used to build the dynamic simulation model (Ding, 2011). The numerical models before and after loading are shown in Figure 2; f is the applied micro-force, d is the diameter of the bubble, t is the thickness of the bubble and b is the deformation of the bubble. We assume that the inner pressure is equal to outer pressure, the gas in the bubble is incompressible and thermostatic, the deadweight of the bubble is ignored, and one-eighth of the bubble diameter is restricted, as shown in Figure 2. In the experimental equipment shown in Figure 1, the bubble shelf also occupies one-eighth of the bubble diameter, which is the same with the numerical calculation.

caption.p: Numerical calculating model of spherical film: (a) before loading; (b) after loading.

sec.p: The spherical film is a type of a water-soluble film. It is very soft with a density of 960 kg/m3, which is close to that of water, and the thickness is about 700 nm. Ohl and Klaseboer (2010) simulated an oscillating bubble near various bio-materials (brain and cornea) using the boundary element method (BEM). The bio-materials were modelled as an elastic fluid with different Young’s moduli and density. They found that the bubble tended to split into two or more bubbles when it was oscillating near soft bio-materials. In addition, Karakashev et al. (2010) monitored the film tension using a commercial profile analysis tensiometer (Sinterface Technologies, GmbH). The elastic moduli of foam bubbles were obtained as a function of surfactant concentration in the range of 2×10−3–1×10−2 M. According to the research of Ohl and Klaseboer (2010), and Karakashev et al. (2010), the elastic modulus of the film is taken to be 20 kPa and the Poisson ration is set as 0.45. Figure 3 shows the dynamic model of the spherical film when micro-force is applied on the top and centre of the bubble.

sec.title: Orthogonal experiments and calculation results
sec.p: The orthogonal experiment method is used to make an experimental scheme to reduce the number of times that the experiment must be repeated to obtain good results (Shen and Wen, 2005). According to the relations between the spherical film diameter, spherical film thickness, applied micro-force and spherical film deformation, the spherical film deformation is chosen as the observed target, and the other three parameters are set as variable factors. A comprehensive statistics chart containing these three factors and four levels is designed to be assigned to a set of experimental cases (Meng et al., 2009). The values of each factor at different levels are described in Table 1.

caption.p: Factors and levels in the numerical calculating experiments.

sec.p: Based on the orthogonal experiment principle, the values of each factor in Table 1 are divided into 16 groups. In each group of experiments, the parameters related to the numerical model are changed and a different micro-force is loaded on the model in FEM software ANSYS. The experimental results of each group are described in Table 2.

caption.p: Results of orthogonal experiments using spherical film to detect micro-force.

sec.p: In Table 2, Ki represents the average value of the observed target corresponding to each factor when the level of each factor is i. The polar difference value is equal to the difference between the maximum and minimum values of Ki corresponding to each factor. A large polar difference value under each factor column means that the factor is the main factor influencing the observed target. Looking at the values of Ki and polar difference, we can confirm that the thickness is the primary factor affecting the experimental results or observed target, namely the deformation of the bubble. Inversely, the deformation of the bubble is minimally affected by the spherical film diameter. The subsequent section will further verify this conclusion. The values of polar difference in the two empty columns are 0.07 and 0.092, which are far less than those in the factor columns. Smaller values of the polar difference in the empty column means less influence among factors and the small value also means that we do not omit any important experimental groups.

According to the deformation values calculated from the experimental data in the last column of Table 2, we observe that the minimum deformation value is 0.128 mm in the eighth group and the maximum is 1.387 mm in the 13th group. This is because the thickness is maximum and the load is minimum in the eighth group, whereas the thickness is minimum and the load is maximum in the 13th group.

sec.title: Formula fitting and error analysis
sec.p: The orthogonal experiments provide multiple groups of data and the approximate relation among the four parameters can be obtained based on the quantitative analysis method. However, the relation is not clear and it is not sufficient to guide the future experiments. The least square method based on singular value decomposition (Gao et al., 2011; Wang and Ding, 2008) is used to obtain the equation relating spherical film deformation, spherical film diameter, spherical film thickness and nN force. Studying Equation (4) shows that spherical film deformation b is almost proportional to the micro-force f within a certain range, and b has a negative and exponential relation to both spherical film diameter d and spherical film thickness t.

In order to assure the correctness of Equation (4), we analyse the error of deformation b between the numerical calculation and formula calculation. Substituting values of three parameters d, t and f from Table 2 into Equation (4), we obtain a group of deformation values that are theoretical values of deformation b. The values of deformation b in Table 2 are experimental values. sec.p: In Table 3, the difference between the theoretical deformation and experimental deformation is rather small. The minimum fitting error is 0.08% and the maximum is 3.18%. The error is not more than ±3.2%. Thus, the fitting formula is very accurate.

To observe the proximity between the theoretical values and experimental values of deformation, a 45° zero-error line is used as the standard to draw the points of deformation using the experimental values as abscissae and using the theoretical values as ordinate, as shown in Figure 4. The greater the distance between the point and the zero-error line, the larger the deviation value between the theoretical and experimental value. Figure 4 clearly shows that all data points are distributed near the zero-error line.

The errors of deformation b are distributed in approximately ±3%, as shown in Figure 5. If the deformation b is in the range 0.18–1.1 mm, the error values are distributed from −3% to 1% with better concentration. The distribution of deformation b in Figure 4 and error distribution in Figure 5 both demonstrate the accuracy of Equation (4).

sec.title: Discussion of parameters
sec.p: Equation (4) shows the relations between bubble deformation b and the other three parameters: spherical film diameter d, spherical film thickness t and micro-force f loaded on the spherical film. The specific relations between the bubble deformation and each parameter should be discussed in the following three different situations:

list-item.p: in the case of the same load but different thickness, how the deformation changes as the diameter changes;
in the case of the same diameter but different load, how the deformation changes as the thickness changes;
in the case of the same thickness but different diameter, how the deformation changes as the load changes.

sec.p: In situation 1, the diameter is an independent variable and the deformation is a dependent variable. Setting different thickness values, we can obtain a curve family relating deformation and diameter under different thickness values. Analogously, we can obtain a curve family relating deformation and thickness under different load values in situation 2, and a curve family relating deformation and load under different diameter values in situation 3. The curve family describing the variation trend between deformation and each independent variable is shown in Figures 3–5. As long as the selected value does not depart much from the allowed range, Equation (4) can satisfy the accuracy requirements.

According to the variation trend of the fitting curve and the distribution of the data points in Figure 6, we can conclude that the deformation value changes slowly as the diameter changes, and the variation trend between the deformation and the diameter is almost consistent under different thickness values. Besides, the fitting curves go through most of the data points when the diameter is in the range 40–60 mm, meeting the experimental requirements. For the curve family of different thicknesses, the consistency is better for thicknesses greater than 0.7 μm. The data points deviate greatly from the fitting curve when the diameter is 30 mm. The diameter of 30 mm is small and not suitable for future experiments. Consequently, the diameter value at this point can be regarded as a jump error, and can be ignored.

caption.p: Variation trend between deformation and diameter.

sec.p: In the case of fixed values of the spherical film thickness and diameter, the nearly linear relation between the deformation and the external load is well described by Figure 7. The deformation value obviously changes as the load changes. Besides, all data points are also distributed near the fitting curve, better verifying the fitting equation. Since the fitting curves obtained from four different kinds of diameters are distributed near each other, this indicates that the deformation is affected only slightly by the diameter. This is consistent with situation 1, described by the curve family in Figure 6, which also indirectly verifies the small exponential value of the diameter in Equation (4).

caption.p: Variation trend between deformation and load.

sec.p: In the case of fixed values of diameter and micro-force loaded onto a spherical film, the trend of the spherical film deformation changing with thickness according to exponential law is consistent with all the data points shown in Figure 8. In addition, all data points are nearly distributed on the fitting curves, which indirectly indicates that the fitting formula is very accurate. As the load f increases, the deformation also increases in correspondence, which is consistent with the varying trend showed in Figure 7.

caption.p: Variation trend between deformation and thickness.

sec.p: Synthesizing the three situations discussed above, we can conclude that the fitting formula obtained from multiple groups of experimental data is reasonable in a certain range. According to Figures 6–8, in these three independent variables, thickness t influences the deformation b most obviously, load f is in the middle position and diameter d ranks last. The error of the fitting formula is less than ±3.2%, meeting the engineering requirements. Thus, the accuracy and reasonableness of Equation (4) is proved.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: This paper was dedicated to studying the dynamic features of a spherical film to measure micro-force at a nN level. The relations between spherical film deformation, spherical film diameter, spherical film thickness and the applied micro-force on a spherical film were explored. The fitting equation on these four parameters was obtained to show the relations among them as follows:

list-item.p: The error of deformation in the fitting formula was not more than ±3.2% when the external load was in the range of 20–160 nN.
When the diameter was in the range of 40–65 mm, a nearly linear relation was observed between deformation and diameter.
An exponential relationship was observed between deformation and spherical film thickness, when the thickness was in the range 0.5–1.2 μm.
The deformation was found to be directly proportional to the micro-force loaded on special film when the micro-force changed from 20 to 160 nN.
